data.name: ImplementIDisposableInterface
data.value: Implement IDisposable Interface

data.name: TypeOwnsDisposableFieldButIsNotDisposable
data.value: Type '{0}' owns disposable fields but is not disposable

data.name: CustomAttrShouldHaveAttributeUsage
data.value: Custom attributes should have AttributeUsage attribute defined.

data.name: MarkAttributesWithAttributeUsage
data.value: Specify AttributeUsage attribute on '{0}' attribute class.

data.name: DefineAccessorsForAttributeArguments
data.value: Define accessors for attribute arguments.

data.name: DefineAccessorsForAttributeArgumentsDefault
data.value: Add a public read-only property accessor for positional argument '{0}' of attribute '{1}'.

data.name: DefineAccessorsForAttributeArgumentsIncreaseVisibility
data.value: If '{0}' is the property accessor for positional argument '{1}', ensure that property getter is public.

data.name: DefineAccessorsForAttributeArgumentsRemoveSetter
data.value: Remove the property setter from '{0}' or reduce its accessibility because it corresponds to positional argument '{1}'.

data.name: OverloadOperatorEqualsOnIComparableInterface
data.value: Overload operator Equals and comparison operators when implementing System.IComparable

data.name: OverloadOperatorEqualsOnIComparableInterfaceDescription
data.value: Types that implement IComparable should redefine Equals and comparison operators to keep the meanings of less than, greater than, and equals consistent throughout the type.

data.name: CreatePropertyAccessorForParameter
data.value: Create a property accessor.

data.name: ImplementComparable
data.value: Implement Equality and Comparison methods and operators

data.name: MakeGetterPublic
data.value: Make the getter of the property public

data.name: MakeSetterNonPublic
data.value: Make the setter of the property non-public

data.name: OverloadOperatorEqualsOnOverridingValueTypeEquals
data.value: Overload operator equals on overriding ValueType.Equals

data.name: OverloadOperatorEqualsOnOverridingValueTypeEqualsDescription
data.value: Value types that redefine System.ValueType.Equals should redefine the equality operator as well to ensure that these members return the same results. This helps ensure that types that rely on Equals (such as ArrayList and Hashtable) behave in a manner that is expected and consistent with the equality operator.

data.name: OverloadOperatorEqualsOnOverridingValueTypeEquals1
data.value: Overload operator equals on overriding ValueType.Equals

data.name: MarkAssembliesWithCLSCompliantAttribute
data.value: Mark assemblies with CLSCompliantAttribute

data.name: MarkAssembliesWithCLSCompliantDescription
data.value: Assemblies should explicitly state their CLS compliance using the CLSCompliant attribute. An assembly without this attribute is not CLS-compliant. Assemblies, modules, and types can be CLS-compliant even if some parts of the assembly, module, or type are not CLS-compliant. The following rules apply: 1) If the element is marked CLSCompliant, any noncompliant members must have the CLSCompliant attribute present with its argument set to false. 2) A comparable CLS-compliant alternative member must be supplied for each member that is not CLS-compliant.

data.name: AssembliesShouldBeMarkedWithAssemblyVersionAttribute
data.value: Assemblies should be marked with AssemblyVersionAttribute

data.name: MarkAllAssembliesWithComVisible
data.value: Mark all assemblies with ComVisible

data.name: MarkAllAssembliesWithComVisibleDescription
data.value: The System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComVisible attribute indicates whether COM clients can use the library. Good design dictates that developers explicitly indicate COM visibility. The default value for this attribute is 'true'. However, the best design is to mark the assembly ComVisible false, and then mark types, interfaces, and individual members as ComVisible true, as appropriate.

data.name: CA1017_AttributeTrue
data.value: Consider changing the ComVisible attribute on {0} to false, and opting in at the type level.

data.name: CA1017_NoAttribute
data.value: Because {0} exposes externally visible types, mark it with ComVisible(false) at the assembly level and then mark all types within the assembly that should be exposed to COM clients with ComVisible(true).

data.name: AvoidUnsealedAttributes
data.value: Avoid unsealed attributes.

data.name: SealAttributeTypesForImprovedPerf
data.value: Seal attribute types for improved performance. Sealing attribute types speeds up performance during reflection on custom attributes.

data.name: AvoidUnsealedAttributesCodeFix
data.value: Seal attribute type.

data.name: StringComparisonShouldBeOrdinalDescription
data.value: For non-linguistic comparisons, StringComparison.Ordinal or StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase should be used instead of the linguistically-sensitive StringComparison.InvariantCulture.

data.name: StringComparisonShouldBeOrdinalOrOrdinalIgnoreCase
data.value: String comparison should use StringComparison.Ordinal or StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase

data.name: DisposableFieldsShouldBeDisposed
data.value: Disposable fields should be disposed

data.name: DoNotMarkEnumsWithFlags
data.value: Do not mark Enum with FlagsAttribute

data.name: DoNotMarkEnumsWithFlagsDescription
data.value: The enumeration does not appear to contain a consistent set values that can be combined using the OR (|) and AND (&amp;amp;) operators. Using the Flags attribute on an enumeration suggests that the enumeration values are meant to be combined using the AND and OR operators. Typically, a flags enumeration uses values that are either powers of two, or combine other values that are powers of two.

data.name: DoNotMarkEnumsWithFlagsMessage
data.value: '{0}' is marked with FlagsAttribute but a discrete member cannot be found for every settable bit that is used across the range of enum values. Remove FlagsAttribute from the type or define new members for the following (currently missing) values: '{1}'.

data.name: MarkEnumsWithFlags
data.value: Mark Enum with FlagsAttribute

data.name: MarkEnumsWithFlagsDescription
data.value: The enumeration appears to be made up of combinable flags. If this true, apply the Flags attribute to the enumeration.

data.name: MarkEnumsWithFlagsMessage
data.value: The constituent members of '{0}' appear to represent flags that can be combined rather than discrete values. If this is correct, mark the enumeration with FlagsAttribute.

data.name: DoNotMarkEnumsWithFlagsCodeFix
data.value: Remove FlagsAttribute from enum.

data.name: MarkEnumsWithFlagsCodeFix
data.value: Apply FlagsAttribute to enum.

data.name: DoNotLockOnObjectsWithWeakIdentity
data.value: Do not lock on objects with weak identity.

data.name: DoNotLockOnWeakIdentity
data.value: Do not lock on a reference of type '{0}' as it has weak identity. Replace that with a lock against an object with strong identity.

data.name: UseGenericEventHandlerInstances
data.value: Use System.EventHandler<T> where T inherits System.EventArgs or use System.EventHandler
